title: 113_hr1062
content: The "SEC Regulatory Accountability Act" requires the Securities and Exchange Commission to consider the costs and benefits of its regulations and certain agency actions. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require the Commission to consider costs and benefits before issuing regulations under the securities laws. The Chief Economist must assess both qualitative and quantitative aspects to justify the regulation's benefits outweighing the costs. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment requires the Commission to assess costs and benefits before issuing regulations under securities laws. The Commission must identify alternatives, ensure regulations are accessible and written in plain language, and seek to improve regulatory results. The Commission must assess costs and benefits of regulatory alternatives, including not regulating, to maximize net benefits. This includes considering if rulemaking will promote efficiency, competition, and capital formation. The Commission must evaluate regulations to minimize burden on society, consider costs, and assess compatibility with other regulations. When determining the costs and benefits of a regulation, the Commission must consider its impact on investor choice, market liquidity, and small businesses. The Commission is also required to explain received comments on potential costs or benefits and provide responses in the final rule. The SEC Regulatory Accountability Act requires the Commission to review its regulations every 5 years to determine if they are outdated, ineffective, or burdensome, and make necessary modifications. The SEC Regulatory Accountability Act requires the Commission to review regulations every 5 years for effectiveness and burden. Issuers with a public float of $250,000,000 or less are subject to reporting requirements under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, with consideration given to the burden of regulation compared to its benefits. Post-adoption impact assessments are required for major rule changes, stating purposes and consequences. The SEC Regulatory Accountability Act mandates the Commission to assess regulations every 5 years for effectiveness and burden. Issuers with a public float of $250,000,000 or less must comply with Sarbanes-Oxley Act reporting requirements, considering the regulatory burden versus benefits. Post-implementation assessments must include quantitative and qualitative metrics, an assessment plan supervised by the Chief Economist, and identification of any potential unintended consequences. The assessment plan required under the SEC Regulatory Accountability Act must consider costs, benefits, unintended consequences, data collection methods, analysis, job impacts, and differentiate between public and private sector jobs. The Chief Economist will submit the assessment report. The Chief Economist must submit the assessment report to the Commission within 2 years of the adopting release, with the possibility of an extension if necessary. The final report will be published in the Federal Register for notice and comment within 7 days of submission. Any necessary modifications to the plan will be made to assess unforeseen aspects or consequences. The assessment plan for regulations must be promptly published in the Federal Register for notice and comment. Data collection specified in the plan at least 30 days before final regulation adoption is not subject to notice and comment requirements. The Commission must publish the assessment plan for regulations in the Federal Register for notice and comment. Any material modifications requiring new data collection not previously published must also be exempt from requirements if notice for comment is given at least 30 days prior to data collection initiation. Final action must be taken within 180 days of the assessment report publication, either proposing to amend or rescind the regulation or publishing a new one for comment. The Commission must take final action within 180 days of the assessment report publication, either proposing to amend or rescind the regulation, or publishing a notice that no action will be taken. The term 'regulation' refers to an agency statement of general applicability designed to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy. The Commission must take final action within 180 days of the assessment report publication on regulations, excluding certain types like those related to formal rulemaking, agency organization, statutory compliance prohibition, and emergency actions. The Congress expects the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board to comply with section 23(e) requirements. The Securities and Exchange Commission must approve rules from other regulatory entities like the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board before they take effect. The Clerk, Karen L. Haas, attests.
